Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Exploring the evolution of leaf development using the moss Physcomitrella patens

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our planet hosts an astounding assortment of multicellular organisms, which come in an incredible array of sizes, shapes, and colors. At the heart of this diversity are differences in the process by which organisms develop from a single-celled zygote to their adult form, often composed of trillions of cells organized in hundreds of tissue types. An understanding of the genes controlling this process holds the promise of furthering medical advancements from cancer treatment to stem cell therapy.

As the genomes of more and more organisms were sequenced, scientists were surprised to find that the "genetic toolbox" controlling development is similar across very different species – for example, people and fruit flies. This suggests that as new structures (like insect wings) evolve, genes that previously had another function in development are 'hijacked' for a new role.

To gain insight into the way that genes can acquire a new function in development over the course of evolution, we are studying the genes in the miR390-dependent ta-siRNA pathway, which is known to be important in flowering plants for the development of leaves and meristems (the stem cell compartments of plants). Most of the genes that make up this pathway have been found in a moss, Physcomitrella patens, which split from the ancestors of flowering plants about 150 million years before they evolved leaves or true meristems. Thus, the miR390-dependent ta-siRNA pathway likely had a yet unknown role in the development of ancient plants, which was hijacked later on in evolution to function in leaf and meristem development.

To shed light on these genes' ancestral function, we mutated a number of them in moss. The EAPSI program allowed me to visit the lab of Dr. Mitsuyasu Hasebe in Japan to learn techniques in analyzing these mutant moss plants and to gain a better understanding of moss biology and evolution. We found that the miR390-dependent ta-siRNA pathway is likely important in organ architecture and growth in moss, and may even function in stem cell regulation. We are continuing to explore these aspects of moss development in collaboration with the Hasebe lab.

We have also applied the skills I acquired during my time in the Hasebe lab to develop high-school level education material on evolution. Although a century of research in genetics and molecular biology has greatly expanded our understanding of evolution, the subject is often presented in biology classes as it was understood when Darwin first proposed his theory 150 years ago. This makes the vibrant, modern field of evolutionary biology seem stagnant and uninteresting to students. We developed a day-long laboratory exercise in evolutionary biology, centered around working with one of the moss strains analyzed by me in Dr. Hasebe's Lab, and incorporated it into a summer high school-level course on plant genetics held at Cold Spring Harbor's DNA Learning Center (DNALC). We are now working on making this class a permanent part of the summer program, as well as incorporating more evolutionary biology into other courses held at the DNALC.
